claim: Americans earn less  than people in certain countries.

supporting.text: According to World Bank data, the median household income in the United States is higher than in most countries, including many developed nations.

attacks.text: According to World Bank data, the median household income in the United States is higher than in most countries, including many developed nations.
Median income does not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in the U.S. compared to many other countries.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), U.S. median income remains higher than in most countries.
The World Bank data excludes certain high-income countries like Switzerland and Norway where median incomes are higher than in the U.S.
When including tax burdens and social benefits, take-home pay in some European countries exceeds U.S. levels despite lower gross incomes.

supporting.text: Countries like Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway have higher average wages than the United States, as reported by OECD statistics.

attacks.text: Countries like Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway have higher average wages than the United States, as reported by OECD statistics.
OECD statistics do not account for cost of living differences, which are significantly higher in Switzerland, Luxembourg, and Norway compared to the U.S.
Even after adjusting for purchasing power parity (PPP), median wages in these countries often remain higher than in the U.S., as shown by IMF data.
The OECD data reflects averages, which can be skewed by high earners; median income comparisons show a narrower gap.
Median income comparisons still favor some of these countries, especially when accounting for social benefits like healthcare and education.

supporting.text: The U.S. has significant income inequality, meaning while some Americans earn very high wages, others earn significantly less than workers in some other high-income countries.

attacks.text: The U.S. has significant income inequality, meaning while some Americans earn very high wages, others earn significantly less than workers in some other high-income countries.
Median income in the U.S. is higher than in most other high-income countries, which suggests that the average American earns more, not less.
Median income comparisons can be misleading because they don't account for cost of living differences, which are higher in the U.S. than in many other countries.
Income inequality in the U.S. is not unique; many other high-income countries also have significant disparities, so the claim doesn't distinguish the U.S. from those countries.
While income inequality exists elsewhere, the U.S. has one of the highest Gini coefficients among developed nations, indicating more severe inequality.

supporting.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that some countries with nominally higher wages have lower real incomes due to higher costs of living.

attacks.text: Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show that some countries with nominally higher wages have lower real incomes due to higher costs of living.
PPP adjustments are not universally standardized and can vary significantly depending on the methodology used.
Major organizations like the World Bank and IMF use standardized PPP methodologies that are widely accepted.
Some high-cost countries still have significantly higher disposable incomes even after PPP adjustments.
Disposable income comparisons often exclude non-monetary benefits like healthcare and education, which vary by country.

supporting.text: Certain professions in the U.S., such as software engineers and doctors, earn more than their counterparts in many other countries, while lower-wage workers may earn less.

attacks.text: Certain professions in the U.S., such as software engineers and doctors, earn more than their counterparts in many other countries, while lower-wage workers may earn less.

The claim refers to average earnings, not specific professions. Even if some high-earning professions in the U.S. outearn their counterparts, the overall average earnings in certain countries may still be higher.
Average earnings can be misleading due to income inequality. The U.S. has a higher Gini coefficient than many developed nations, meaning the median wage may be a better comparison.
Many countries with higher average earnings have significantly higher costs of living, meaning higher nominal wages don't necessarily translate to greater purchasing power.
Purchasing power parity (PPP) adjustments show U.S. workers still earn less than those in several countries when accounting for cost of living differences.

supporting.text: Taxation and social benefits in some European countries result in higher net disposable incomes for workers compared to the U.S., despite lower gross wages.

attacks.text: Taxation and social benefits in some European countries result in higher net disposable incomes for workers compared to the U.S., despite lower gross wages.
Higher taxation in European countries can reduce disposable income for high earners, making the net benefit less universal than implied.
Many European countries have progressive tax systems that still leave middle and lower-income workers with higher net disposable incomes compared to the U.S.
Cost of living in many European countries is significantly higher than in the U.S., offsetting the benefits of higher net disposable income.
Social benefits like healthcare and education in Europe reduce out-of-pocket expenses, compensating for higher cost of living.
